author: nordbjerg
content: what PR changed `assert auth.y_parity < 2**8` from the old value in eip-7702?

author: lightclient
content: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/commit/8628167f34d9022380db5039a0e9d483888d5c4a

author: nordbjerg
content: I can't find the accompanying PR to that commit

author: lightclient
content: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/8929

author: nordbjerg
content: ty

author: nordbjerg
content: what was the motivation to restrict to u8? i think i missed it. asking because this is a departure for other signatures we use in reth and alloy, so this is not super trivial to implement without doing hacky stuff for a while

author: lightclient
content: afaik the motivation was from <@429719902363058177> who even mentioned that it should be limited to a single bit

author: lightclient
content: i think some others also were hoping for this

author: lightclient
content: but yeah, i had the same complaint about the restriction

author: draganrakita
content: Initial idea was to restrict fields, but it morphed into runtime checks that are not great. Should we have it as `u64`?

author: lightclient
content: why u64?

author: lightclient
content: it seems like we should either do u8 as it is the closest to what the actual range is or U256 as it is similar to all other signatures

author: lightclient
content: these are not runtime checks also, weâ€™re talking field restrictions

author: etan_status
content: u8 is fine (the current spec). the other signatures use u256 solely for legacy reasons where the chain ID was encoded into the `v` field.

author: etan_status
content:
libsecp256k1 takes r/s/y as an array[65, byte], and ethereum further limits the final byte to 0/1 (while secp also has 2/3 for some edge cases that don't apply in eth). 

wider `v` is only needed for `LegacyTransaction` which uses 27/28 instead of 0/1 in `v`, and then there was the EIP-155 time when `v` also contained the `chain_id`. none of these legacy items apply for authorizations.

why a limit for authorizations? because invalid authorizations still make it onto the chain, they are skipped over but the data is persisted.
for transactions, that is not a problem because those with invalid `v` get discarded immediately.

author: etan_status
content:
> asking because this is a departure for other signatures
it _is_ different from other signatures, `v` for authorizations behaves differently than for transactions / it doesn't have the legacy functionality

author: lightclient
content: i mean v is only 0 or  1 in every tx type except the legacy type. so it isn't really different from other signatures

author: jochembrouwer
content: For invalid auths to stay the sender has to pay 25k gas, for (raw data) 8+8+20+1+32+32 = 101 bytes (which is much more than encoding 101 bytes in calldata, which would cost 101 * 16 = 1616 gas)

author: lucassaldanhaconsensys
content:
Of course!
```
participants_matrix:
  el:
    - el_type: ethereumjs
      el_image: ethpandaops/ethereumjs:7702-devnet-4-plus-t8ntool-3f3a3cc
  cl:
    - cl_type: teku
      cl_image: ethpandaops/teku:master-b50adc4
    - cl_type: lighthouse
      cl_image: lighthouse-lucas-c8dfe7d:latest
    - cl_type: prysm
      cl_image: ethpandaops/prysm-beacon-chain:develop-ffc443b
network_params:
  electra_fork_epoch: 1
  min_validator_withdrawability_delay: 1
  shard_committee_period: 1
  churn_limit_quotient: 16
  num_validator_keys_per_node: 64
additional_services:
  - dora
  - apache
  - assertoor
dora_params:
  image: "ethpandaops/dora:pk910-electra-devnet4"
snooper_enabled: true
assertoor_params:
  run_stability_check: false
  run_block_proposal_check: false
```
